:: Risks associated with being overweight ::


1.High blood pressure 
Higher levels of LDL cholesterol(bad cholesterol) 
2.lower levels of HDL cholesterol(good cholesterol) 
3.high levels of triglycerides 
4.Type II diabetes 
5.Coronary heart disease 
6.Stroke 
7.Gallbladder disease 
8.Osteoarthritis, a type of joint disease caused by breakdown of joint cartilage 
9.Sleep apnea and breathing problems 
10.Certain cancers (endometrial, breast, colon, kidney, gallbladder, liver) 
11.Low quality of life 
12.Mental illnesses such as clinical depression, anxiety, and others 
13.Body pains and difficulty with certain physical functions 
14.Generally, an increased risk of mortality compared to those with a healthy BMI




:: Risks associated with being underweight ::


1.Malnutrition, vitamin deficiencies, anemia (lowered ability to carry blood vessels) 
2.Osteoporosis, a disease that causes bone weakness, increasing the risk of breaking a bone 
3.A decrease in immune function 
4.Growth and development issues, particularly in children and teenagers 
5.Possible reproductive issues for women due to hormonal imbalances that can disrupt the menstrual cycle. Underweight women also have a higher chance of miscarriage in the first trimester 
6.Potential complications as a result of surgery 
7.Generally, an increased risk of mortality compared to those with a healthy BMI 
In some cases, being underweight can be a sign of some underlying condition or disease such as anorexia nervosa, which has its own risks.
